Steven Avery was a shining example of

we chose Steven Avery as our subject
because here was a man who had been
failed by the system in 1985 and and was
now stepping back into it 20 years later
you know we viewed that it's this
amazing opportunity to sort of do a
check up on the American criminal
justice system how much had it advanced
and if not far enough what more could be
done when you started this did you have
a view on the case no I mean we we did
not set out to convict or exonerate
Steven Avery you know we were there to
document the Halbach case as it was
unfolding and really to try to
understand the historical context for
that case so we wanted to go back and
understand how the wrongful conviction
in 1985 came about what were some of the
contributing factors and to try to see
whether there had been significant
enough advances in the system so that
there wouldn't be the same failure in
2005 now one of the criticisms has been
leveled at at the series is that the
facts that you have put on display do
not portray an accurate picture of what
the prosecution had to say in the case
what what do you say to that I disagree
with respect to particular pieces of
evidence of course we left out evidence
this was a ten part documentary series
that spans 30 years it wasn't just an
invest well actually it wasn't an
investigation into the Halbach murder it
was actually a window into how Steven
Avery was prosecuted and with respect to
particular pieces of physical evidence
what was left out in our opinion was
much less significant than what was
included your presence there during all
of this in a pretty small community do
you think you in any way influenced
events by actually
being there and recording them and being
so close to the Avery family I mean I
think as a documentarian you always have
that question just your your literal
presence the presence of a camera does
that change what's going on but we were
very careful we you know laura has a law
background we knew this was a pending
case we never asked people about the
facts of the case we were there to
document people's experiences and you
know I would argue that we had much less
of an impact on anything that was going
on than any other member of the media or
journalist who was there who was playing
a very active role in the case we shot
one point member of the media
essentially talking about a case being a

different well I I think our motives for
making this series had nothing to do
with ratings whereas I think news
directors are concerned with their
ratings but surely you are concerned
that this gets a wide audience I mean
it's it isn't what's what's so different
about it well it's our process is
different I mean ours was much more
organic I would say you mentioned that
Steven Avery you know was at the center
of our story I mean we chose him to be
our main subject we wanted to put a
human face on the experience of an
accused in America and what is it like
you know to be accused what is it like
to stand trial in a high-profile case
and what does it like to do so when your
antagonist law enforcement has a vested
interest in the outcome of your trial
that is your guilt I think - sure of
just wanted to get quick results and get
to get a suspect behind bars
I was absolutely devastating
it's like why would they arrest Eve for
that that was so out of his character
people believed he did it though because
he was an Avery you know here was a
family that had already endured the

was a family that actually knew he was
innocent in 1985 and you know for
another two decades it wasn't a family
that just believed in their hearts he
couldn't have committed the crime they
were with him yeah on July 29th of 1985
and they knew that he hadn't convicted
it yet he hadn't committed the crime yet
there was nothing they could do to help
him and here they were 20 years later
Stephen was back in custody and once
again proclaiming his innocence and they
felt just as helpless and felt like they
had no additional options nothing beyond
what they had in 1985 they had to rely
on the very system that had failed him
20 years prior and beyond the legal

did you reach about the way society
deals with a family like the Avery's
because it's not simply about the
justice system it's about how the
community related to them isn't it I
mean this isn't just a you know a legal
thriller or a legal documentary I mean
it's really a story about human beings
and how we treat each other and the
importance of you know having empathy
for people that aren't like you and in
treating them the way you would want to
be treated yourself you know as Laura
mentioned you know we chose Stephen
we're telling the story of what it's
like to be accused and asking viewers
you know is this how you would want to

criticisms that Teresa Halbach doesn't
really come alive in what is quite a
long 10 hours of programming why not why
why did you not focus on her as well
well I think we would have we would have
wanted to be able to include more about
her that would have taken the
participation of people in her life to
do so so we
try to do what we could with the
materials that we did have clearly she
is a victim in this story and you know
if the person who murdered her is not in
